Award.AwardTitle: EMSW21-MCTP: Institute for Mathematics at North Carolina State University. (I'M at State)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal aims to improve the retention of graduate students in the first two years and increase the number of students going to graduate school. We do this by incorporating students in research and the mathematical community earlier and providing support programs for pre-graduate students. The main component is a set of interconnected summer programs involving research experiences and short courses for students. These are designed to engage them and encourage them to continue in mathematics. Several parts of this proposal are directly aimed at underrepresented students. The major programs include the following. (1) Research for Early Graduate Students (REG), designed to sustain the enthusiasm for collaborative original research that attracts students to Ph.D. programs by providing them with research experiences during the early years of graduate work. (2) Research and enrichment experiences for under-represented undergraduate students (REU+), designed to provide a supportive REU experience for underrepresented students who may not usually consider an REU program. An important feature is the inclusion of established mentors of underrepresented students to work with the program and us. (3) Enhanced Research Program for Early Graduates (REG+), a one-year program for students who have graduated from college and are not quite prepared for graduate studies in mathematics. This program targets underrepresented groups. The program includes a summer research experience, a year of remedial course work and significant mentoring.


Four important groups are included: underrepresented undergraduate students, post-baccalaureate students considering returning to mathematics, under-prepared graduate students, and early graduate students. In particular, this grant features a collaborative effort between faculty at NCSU, and the Mathematics Departments of 6 Historically Black Colleges and Universities. We aim to increase the number of underrepresented students who get graduate degrees in Mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to provide a dynamic supportive environment that welcomes, nurtures and stimulates young mathematics students to reach their full potentials. Students work on research problems in a supportive, collaborative environment that is part of a vibrant research department with strong ties to industry and government laboratories. Four important groups of students are included: underrepresented undergraduate students, post-baccalaureate stu- dents considering returning to mathematics, under-prepared graduate students, and early graduate students. 

Among our graduate students who participated in this project we have had better than 95% retention rate (compared to less than 70% historically). They have proceeded to pass the PhD qualifying exams, choose advisors and finish their degrees in less time than other students. Rather than be distracted by the early research it has indeed motivated them to find a thesis direction and make quick progress to degree completion. Before this project the time to completion ranged from 5.00-6.05 years for students finishing in the 3-year period 2005-2008, while currently it is 4.5-5 years for the period 2011-14. The average number of students graduating annually increased from a range of 8.33-13.00 in 2005-2008 to a range of 15.00-16.00 in 2011-2014. The rise in retention rate is even more impressive for the populations who historically dropped out the most, that is students from smaller schools, and from underrepresented groups whose drop out rate was more than 50% are now staying and completing degrees at the same rate as all students. 

In addition, this is the only funded post- baccalaureate program in mathematics at a university in the country. This program has done exactly what we’ve hoped. During this project, there have been 7 postbac students at North Carolina State University. All of them have come from underrepresented groups. Students spent their year taking both graduate and undergraduate courses and participated in a summer research experience. They also received mentoring and participated in community building activities. All the former postbacs have now gone on to group 1 or 2 graduate programs in mathematics. 

The success of this project and its impact on the diversity in the mathematics work force was recognized by the American Mathematical Society (AMS) with two national awards. In 2010 we received the AMS Award for an Exemplary Program or Achievement in a Mathematics Department and in 2011 we received the AMS Award for Mathematics Programs that Make a Difference. We are the only program to receive both AMS awards back-to-back.
